questions.text: A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of an intermittent burning sensation in his chest. The sensation becomes prominent when he is lying in bed and is also present after eating heavy meals. He also states that his breath has an unpleasant odor in the morning. He has not lost any weight during this period. He has hypertension. His father died of colon cancer and his mother has hypothyroidism. He drinks 2–3 beers on weekends; he does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. His medications include ramipril and an over-the-counter multivitamin. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Results of a complete blood count are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic examination of the esophagus to screen for adenocarcinoma is reserved for patients with GERD and alarm symptoms (e.g., dysphagia, odynophagia, anemia, GI bleeding, unintentional weight loss). It is also indicated to screen for Barrett esophagus in patients with chronic GERD symptoms (weekly for ≥ 5 years) and three or more additional risk factors: male sex, age > 50 years, White ethnicity, obesity, smoking, family history of Barrett esophagus or esophageal adenocarcinoma in a first-degree relative. This patient does not meet the criteria for endoscopy at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

H. pylori testing via urea breath test is indicated in patients with dyspepsia (i.e., epigastric pain or burning that lasts for ≥ 1 month) if they are < 60 years of age and do not have red flags for dyspepsia. This patient, however, has typical heartburn (intermittent retrosternal pain exacerbated by eating and lying down), the classic symptom of GERD. H. pylori testing is not recommended in the workup of typical GERD (i.e., in patients without dyspepsia in whom neither PUD nor gastritis is suspected). The prevalence of H. pylori infection among patients with GERD is not greater than in the general population. Test results would not help in the decision for or against the treatment of H. pylori infection in this patient group. Other indications for H. pylori testing include active peptic ulcer disease (PUD), a past history of PUD, atrophic gastritis, and/or gastric MALT lymphomas.

C) CORRECT:

Empiric therapy with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) is the most appropriate initial step in the management of recent-onset GERD with no red flag symptoms of GERD (e.g., dysphagia, odynophagia, anemia, GI bleeding, unintentional weight loss, persistent vomiting, aspiration pneumonia) and little to no risk factors for Barrett esophagus. Of all medications that are used to treat GERD, PPIs are associated with the greatest reduction in symptoms and relapse rates. In addition to a trial of PPIs for 8 weeks, certain lifestyle modifications (e.g., smoking cessation, weight loss, elevating the head of the bed while sleeping, avoiding late-night meals) should be recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

H2 receptor antagonists (H2RAs) is the second-line treatment for patients with GERD because they are less effective than first-line drugs in providing symptomatic relief, reducing relapse rates, and promoting healing of erosive lesions of the esophagus. H2RAs also have a shorter duration of action (about 12 hours) than first-line drugs.

Bedtime administration of H2RAs may be considered as adjunctive therapy for patients with symptoms refractory to first-line therapy. However, this patient has not yet received the first-line therapy and should therefore not be given an H2RA.

E) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow is the confirmatory test for esophageal diverticula (e.g., Zenker diverticulum), which can manifest with halitosis and retrosternal discomfort, mimicking GERD. However, Zenker diverticulum is more common in men > 60 years of age; moreover, additional symptoms, such as dysphagia and regurgitation of undigested food, are also expected in patients with an esophageal diverticulum.

Studies have shown that barium swallows have a very low sensitivity (approx. 25%) for diagnosing gastroesophageal reflux, and therefore, should not be used for the diagnosis of GERD when a patient presents with typical symptoms of uncomplicated GERD in the absence of dysphagia.
Image Description:

The predominantely left-sided, dorsal contrast-filled structure in the upper esophagus most likely indicates Zenker diverticulum.

F) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin and clarithromycin are used in combination with proton pump inhibitors as a part of the triple therapy eradication regimen in patients with H. pylori infection. However, treatment of H. pylori infection is not indicated in patients with GERD alone, since the prevalence of H. pylori infection among patients with GERD is not greater than in the general population. In fact, the prevalence of H. pylori is actually lower in patients with complicated or severe GERD.

G) INCORRECT:

Antacids, such as calcium carbonate, can be used for symptomatic relief in patients with mild GERD symptoms that occur less than once a week. However, because of their short duration of action, they are not used for the prevention of GERD-related symptoms. This patient, who experiences persistent symptoms, should receive a more effective form of therapy.
questions.hint: The burning sensation in this patient's chest, exacerbated by consuming heavy meals and lying down, is consistent with heartburn, which, along with halitosis, is suggestive of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician with a 12-year history of recurrent heartburn. He has also had a cough, which is worse at night, for the past year. He has not seen a physician for 8 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. His only medication is an over-the-counter antacid. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (209 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no lymphadenopathy. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Results of a complete blood count are within the reference ranges. An upper endoscopy shows dark pink mucosa up to 2 cm proximal to the gastroesophageal junction. Biopsy samples of the mucosa show columnar epithelium with goblet cells and low-grade dysplasia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic surveillance is an acceptable alternative to more invasive treatment options for patients with BE and confirmed low-grade dysplasia but it should be performed sooner in 6 months and yearly thereafter.

For patients who have macroscopic findings consistent with BE on endoscopy but no evidence of intestinal metaplasia on biopsy, repeat endoscopic surveillance with biopsy should be performed at 1–2 years because a third of these patients will subsequently develop intestinal metaplasia. Repeat endoscopic surveillance after a longer interval of 3–5 years is recommended for patients with BE and intestinal metaplasia but no dysplasia.

B) CORRECT:

Endoscopic eradication of dysplasia via mucosal resection and concurrent eradication of intestinal metaplasia is the treatment of choice for BE because of the risk of malignant transformation to esophageal adenocarcinoma. BE with low-grade dysplasia may be managed with surveillance endoscopy after 6 months and yearly therafter, because the risk of transformation is lower in this patient group compared to patients with BE with high-grade dysplasia (approx. 0.7% per year vs. approx. 7% per year).

Endoscopic eradication therapy is also indicated in the management of certain patients with stage T1a esophageal adenocarcinoma (i.e., with intact muscularis propria).

C) INCORRECT:

Esophagectomy is indicated in the treatment of esophageal adenocarcinomas in suitable surgical candidates and may be combined with neoadjuvant chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy in patients with submucosal invasion. However, it is a complex surgical procedure with considerable morbidity and mortality and should thus only be performed if there is no alternative therapeutic option. Since this patient's biopsy results show low-grade dysplasia of the esophageal mucosa rather than adenocarcinoma, a less invasive treatment is indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Helicobacter pylori eradication therapy (e.g., with optimized bismuth quadruple therapy) is indicated in all patients who test positive for H. pylori infection. Although H. pylori infection cannot be definitively excluded without testing, it is unlikely to be the cause of this patient's BE. Therefore, H. pylori eradication therapy is not the most appropriate next step in management at this point.

Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) such as omeprazole prevent the expansion of intestinal metaplasia and reduce the risk of malignant transformation to invasive carcinoma. Therefore, monotherapy with PPIs plays an important role in maintenance therapy for complications of GERD such as BE.

E) INCORRECT:

External beam radiation therapy (EBRT) in combination with chemotherapy can be considered in the treatment of esophageal cancer. This approach can either be used in a neoadjuvant setting, prior to esophagectomy, or in a palliative setting in patients with metastatic esophageal cancer. EBRT plays no role in the management of patients with BE.

F) INCORRECT:

Antireflux surgery, such as Nissen fundoplication, is used for the long-term management of certain patients with chronic GERD (e.g., those with persistent symptoms despite appropriate medical treatment). However, it cannot prevent malignant transformation in patients who already have BE with dysplastic changes.
questions.hint: This patient with obesity and a long-standing history of smoking and heartburn underwent upper endoscopy to screen for complications of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). The finding of columnar epithelium with goblet cells proximal to the gastroesophageal junction (intestinal metaplasia) indicates Barrett esophagus (BE).

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of intermittent dysphagia. He states that he drinks a lot of water during meals to help reduce the discomfort of swallowing food. He has hypertension and non-erosive gastroesophageal reflux disease. He has smoked one half-pack of cigarettes daily for 32 years. He does not drink alcohol. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and lansoprazole. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 101 kg (222 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft and nontender. A barium esophagram shows a concentric filling defect at the distal esophagus. An upper endoscopy shows a sliding hiatal hernia and a constricting ring at the gastroesophageal junction. Biopsies from the lesion show squamocolumnar epithelium with no metaplasia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Esophagectomy is mainly performed to treat esophageal cancer. Although this patient's dysphagia to solids and findings on barium esophagram are concerning for esophageal cancer, the findings on upper endoscopy and biopsy results are consistent with a Schatzki ring. Therefore, a less invasive treatment is preferred.
Image Description:

Barium esophagram (lateral view) of a patient with esophageal carcinoma

A long segment irregular stricture is seen in the mid third of the thoracic esophagus (green overlay). The superior aspect of the stricture has an apple-core appearance (indicated by dashed line).

B) INCORRECT:

An esophageal stent can be used for palliative treatment of an inoperable esophageal malignancy to allow for the passage of food and liquids. A stent may also be considered to treat refractory strictures. However, other treatment options are available and should first be tried in this patient.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the esophagus

A newly placed self-expanding metal (nitinol) stent is visible. The stent holds the esophagus open as part of the palliative treatment for esophageal cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Intralesional application of corticosteroids can be used to treat Schatzki rings, but it is not the first-line treatment and is rather used for recurrent strictures.

Corticosteroids play a more important role in treating eosinophilic esophagitis, which can also manifest with dysphagia and esophageal rings. However, in eosinophilic esophagitis an endoscopy typically shows linear furrows, eosinophilic abscesses, and multiple esophageal rings, not just a singular constriction. Furthermore, eosinophilic esophagitis more commonly affects younger patients and numerous eosinophils are usually seen on biopsy.
Image Description:

Endoscopic image of the esophagus

Circumferential mucosal lesions (rings/corrugations; examples indicated by blue overlay) are visible.

Yellow lines: longitudinal furrows; Dashed encirclement: Z-line

D) INCORRECT:

Iron supplementation is used to treat Plummer-Vinson syndrome, which also presents with dysphagia. Plummer-Vinson syndrome is associated with esophageal webs on upper endoscopy (which appear thin and membranous; different from the ring seen at the gastroesophageal junction in this patient) and symptoms of severe iron deficiency anemia (e.g., pallor, fatigue, weakness, dyspnea on exertion). This patient's presentation is more consistent with an esophageal ring and he has no features of iron deficiency anemia, therefore iron supplementation is not indicated at this time.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the esophagus

A thin, semilunar membrane (esophageal web; blue overlay) projects into the esophageal lumen. Esophageal webs usually occur in the upper esophagus and do not involve the muscle layer.

Cervical esophageal webs, iron deficiency anemia, and dysphagia form the classic triad of findings in Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has a hiatal hernia, Nissen fundoplication would further narrow the lower esophagus and worsen dysphagia. After treatment of the Schatzki ring, Nissen fundoplication may be considered for treating his sliding hiatal hernia.
Image Description:

Barium swallow, AP radiograph showing the contrast-enhanced esophagus (1), the herniated esophageal sphincter (arrow), the sliding hiatal hernia (2), and the stomach (3) with typical contour.

F) CORRECT:

Mechanical dilation with a bougie or balloon dilator is the first-line treatment for an obstructing Schatzki ring. This procedure provides immediate symptom relief. However, recurrence of strictures is possible and subsequent dilations may be needed. Esophageal rings are thought to arise secondary to chronic damage from gastroesophageal reflux disease.
Image Description:

Barium swallow (lateral view): circular narrowing of the esophagus directly at the esophagogastric junction (Schatzki ring or B-ring). As opposed to A-rings (which are located just proximal to the EG junction), B-rings often can only be seen if there is a concomitant hiatal hernia. with which they are frequently associated (as is the case here).
questions.hint: Dysphagia and circumferential esophageal narrowing, together with normal histology findings, are consistent with a Schatzki ring (esophageal ring).

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up appointment. Two months ago, she was diagnosed with asthma after a 1-year history of a chronic cough and dyspnea with exertion. Her symptoms have improved since starting inhaled albuterol and beclomethasone, but she still coughs most nights when she is lying in bed. Over the past 2 weeks, she has also had occasional substernal chest pain. She does not smoke. She is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (165 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. She has a hoarse voice and frequently clears her throat during the examination. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Pulmonary function tests show an FEV1 of 78% of expected. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) may be considered to evaluate underlying cardiac pathologies. This patient's recurring chest pain, exertional dyspnea, and cough exacerbation when lying supine are possible symptoms of heart failure and lung edema. In some cases, severe mitral valve stenosis may lead to hoarseness due to recurrent laryngeal nerve damage by an enlarged left atrium. However, further signs and symptoms of heart failure such as peripheral pitting edema, increased jugular venous distention, nocturia, and tachycardia would be expected at this point. Moreover, except for obesity, this patient has no risk factors for heart disease (e.g., history of smoking, rheumatic fever, or hypertension), making a different etiology of her symptoms more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Salmeterol is a long-acting beta agonist that is used in the management of moderate chronic asthma. Salmeterol would be a reasonable next step in the escalation of her asthma therapy because this patient currently uses a short-acting beta agonist and a corticosteroid inhaler. However, other comorbidities that potentially worsen asthma should be treated before escalating asthma therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral prednisone is used to treat acute asthma exacerbations or severe, therapy-refractory chronic asthma. This patient does not present with acute dyspnea and wheezing, which makes an acute asthma exacerbation unlikely. In addition, her FEV1 of 78% of predicted indicates moderate asthma severity, which does not warrant an oral corticosteroid therapy.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's persistent cough and substernal chest pain are consistent with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), for which obesity is a risk factor. GERD is a known trigger of asthma and is associated with difficult-to-treat disease. It is thought to worsen asthma as a result of chronic microaspiration of stomach contents into the upper airways as well as an increase in vagal tone. Asthma that worsens when lying down or after meals should raise concern for GERD-induced disease. Since this patient has only had a partial response to her recently initiated asthma medication, a trial of empiric therapy with a proton pump inhibitor is the most appropriate next step in management.

E) INCORRECT:

The methacholine challenge test is used in suspected asthma when pulmonary function tests are inconclusive. This test has a high negative predictive value and is particularly useful for ruling out asthma as a potential diagnosis. This patient's symptoms have been partially responsive to asthma medication and her FEV1 is < 80% of expected, which is consistent with asthma. Therefore, a methacholine challenge test would be superfluous because this patient’s asthma diagnosis has already been confirmed.

F) INCORRECT:

IgE antibodies are involved in type I hypersensitivity reactions, such as allergic asthma, and they can be used as a diagnostic tool. However, this patient shows no signs or symptoms of allergic asthma (e.g., asthma triggered by allergens, such as dust or pollen; a history of atopy) and, therefore, measurement of serum IgE levels is not indicated at this time.
questions.hint: This woman should be evaluated for other conditions that could be worsening her symptoms. Obesity is a risk factor for another common comorbidity associated with asthma.

questions.text: A healthy 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of progressively worsening substernal chest pain after meals. The pain occurs almost daily, becomes severe after he eats spicy foods or drinks coffee, and often wakes him up at night. He has not had any weight loss during this period. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years and he drinks one to two glasses of wine nightly with dinner. Physical examination is unremarkable. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows erythema of the distal esophagus with two small mucosal erosions. Biopsy specimens obtained from the esophagus show no evidence of metaplasia. Without treatment of his current esophageal condition, this patient is most likely to develop which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This was a good option to consider. Reflux esophagitis may lead to the development of Barrett esophagus (BE), which can progress to esophageal adenocarcinoma. However, the risk of malignant transformation of BE to esophageal adenocarcinoma is < 1% per year. This question is meant to test your knowledge of the most common complication of chronic untreated reflux esophagitis, not the most severe complication, so esophageal adenocarcinoma is not the best answer option.

B) INCORRECT:

The most important risk factors for esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) are cigarette smoking and chronic alcohol use. However, GERD with reflux esophagitis does not increase the risk of developing esophageal SCC. Moreover, esophageal SCC typically occurs in the upper two-thirds of the esophagus, whereas this patient has endoscopic evidence of distal esophageal disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for laryngeal carcinoma include cigarette smoking and alcohol consumption, both of which are present in this patient. Reflux of gastric acid into the larynx can cause chronic laryngitis and in severe cases, laryngeal and/or tracheal stenosis. However, laryngeal carcinoma is not a known complication of untreated GERD with esophagitis.

D) CORRECT:

Esophageal strictures are common sequelae of untreated GERD and/or esophagitis. Reflux esophagitis (erosive esophagitis), the most common complication of GERD, is characterized by inflammation of the esophageal mucosa. Esophageal strictures are formed via fibrosis as the inflamed esophageal mucosa heals. Treatment of both reflux esophagitis and GERD consists of lifestyle modifications (e.g., elevation of the head of the bed when sleeping, avoidance of dietary triggers such as spicy food) and acid suppression with proton pump inhibitors.

E) INCORRECT:

Sliding hiatal hernia predisposes to GERD as the laxity of the diaphragmatic esophageal hiatus impairs lower esophageal sphincter function and permits the reflux of gastric contents into the esophagus. GERD, however, does not increase the risk of a hiatal hernia.

F) INCORRECT:

Gastric outlet obstruction (GOO) most commonly occurs as a sequela of peptic ulcer disease (PUD) and develops as a result of inflammation and edema in acute PUD and scarring and fibrosis in chronic PUD. Gastric ulcers typically manifest with postprandial upper abdominal pain worsened by caffeine and spicy foods, whereas duodenal ulcers can cause nocturnal discomfort, similar to the symptoms this patient has. However, this patient's endoscopy findings are in keeping with esophagitis rather than PUD. GOO is not a complication of GERD or esophagitis.
questions.hint: This patient has characteristic symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and evidence of esophagitis on esophagogastroduodenoscopy (esophageal erythema and erosions).

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with gastroesophageal reflux disease comes to the physician because of severe burning chest pain and belching after meals. He has limited his caffeine intake and has been avoiding food close to bedtime. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows erythema and erosions in the distal esophagus. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the most appropriate drug for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Enhancement of the mucosal barrier in the stomach and duodenum is the mechanism of action of sucralfate, which forms a protective barrier, acts as an acid buffer, and promotes HCO3 production. It is commonly used in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease, but is not considered first-line for GERD.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of D2 receptors in the stomach (e.g., metoclopramide) increases lower esophageal sphincter (LES) tone and increases gastric motility. These agents have serious adverse effects (e.g., parkinsonism) and are only considered for patients with GERD and gastroparesis in whom first-line therapy has provided inadequate relief.

C) INCORRECT:

Neutralization of gastric acid is the mechanism of action of antacids such as calcium carbonate. These agents can improve symptoms of GERD, but are mainly used alongside first-line therapy for rapid symptom relief.

D) INCORRECT:

H2 antihistamines, such as cimetidine, inhibit histamine-dependent gastric acid secretion via their antagonistic effect on H2 receptors in the gastric parietal cells. Although they may be used for mild GERD symptoms, they are mainly used as an alternative to first-line medication in maintenance therapy for non-erosive gastroesophageal reflux disease, or in addition to first-line therapy to control nighttime symptoms.

E) CORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) irreversibly inhibit H+/K+ ATPase in parietal cells of the stomach and thus reduce the ATP-dependent secretion of H+ ions into the gastric lumen. They are considered first-line for patients with severe GERD.
Image Description:

Therapeutic approaches include:
– Direct (e.g., proton pump inhibitors) and indirect (e.g., H2 blockers, somatostatin analogs, prostaglandin analogs, atropine) suppression of parietal cell acid production
– Acid neutralization (e.g., antacids)
– Gastric mucosal barrier reinforcement (e.g., prostaglandin analogs)
– Direct coating of gastric mucosal surfaces (e.g., sucralfate, bismuth)
– Disruption of parasympathetic innervation via vagotomy
questions.hint: This patient has symptoms consistent with severe GERD, and evidence of reflux-induced esophagitis. A proton pump inhibitor (PPI) would be the appropriate first-line drug therapy for this patient.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of intermittent retrosternal chest pain. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Endoscopy shows salmon pink mucosa extending 5 cm proximal to the gastroesophageal junction. Biopsy specimens from the distal esophagus show nonciliated columnar epithelium with numerous goblet cells. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Fungal infection of the lower esophagus
Incomplete relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neoplastic proliferation of esophageal epithelium is seen in esophageal cancer. This patient is at increased risk to develop esophageal adenocarcinoma. However, he lacks typical features of an esophageal malignancy such as weight loss, dysphagia, and an ulcerative mass on endoscopy.

B) CORRECT:

Chronic exposure to gastric acid promotes transformation of the stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus to metaplastic columnar epithelium with goblet cells (Barrett esophagus). Barrett esophagus classically occurs in patients with GERD, which commonly presents with intermittent retrosternal pain, as seen in this patient. Diagnosis of Barrett esophagus requires histologic confirmation of intestinal metaplasia.
Image Description:

Comparison of the mucous membrane of a normal distal esophagus to one affected by Barrett metaplasia: In reflux esophagitis, stomach acid damages the stratified squamous epithelium of the distal esophagus, which then becomes replaced by columnar epithelium and goblet cells.

C) INCORRECT:

Atopic inflammation of the esophagus is seen in eosinophilic esophagitis, which is thought to be caused by an abnormal response of the immune system to an antigenic stimulus. Affected individuals commonly present with retrosternal pain, dysphagia to solids, and food impaction. Although this patient presents with retrosternal pain, biopsy would likely show numerous eosinophils within multiple layers of the esophagus rather than metaplastic changes.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypermotile esophageal contractions are seen in spastic disorders of the esophagus (e.g., nutcracker esophagus, diffuse esophageal spasms). Hypermotile esophagus may present with sudden, retrosternal chest pain and a distinctive pattern on barium swallow and manometry. Although this patient does have intermittent retrosternal pain, those conditions would not usually present with mucosal abnormalities.

E) INCORRECT:

Fungal infection of the esophagus can be caused by pathogens such as Candida albicans (esophageal candidiasis). Although it may cause retrosternal pain, as seen here, the absence of risk factors (e.g., immunosuppression) and fungal patches on endoscopy make this diagnosis unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Incomplete relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter occurs in patients with achalasia due to absent or decreased myenteric neurons. Although achalasia can manifest with retrosternal pain, as seen in this patient, it would classically also present with regurgitation and dysphagia of solids and liquids. Endoscopy could possibly show inflammation in case of retained food, but intestinal metaplasia would not be expected.
questions.hint: Esophageal mucosa is normally whitish-pink and composed of stratified squamous epithelium. Intestinal mucosa is normally composed of columnar epithelium with goblet cells.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of recurrent retrosternal chest pain that often wakes her up at night. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Upper endoscopy shows hyperemia in the distal third of the esophagus. A biopsy specimen from this area shows nonkeratinized stratified squamous epithelium with hyperplasia of the basal cell layer and neutrophilic inflammatory infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's findings?

choices.text: Metaplastic transformation of the esophageal epithelium

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased lower esophageal sphincter (LES) tone, as seen in achalasia, typically presents with dysphagia to both solids and liquids, although symptoms of esophageal reflux may also be present. Other features include retrosternal pain and weight loss. This patient does not present with symptoms of dysphagia, making achalasia an unlikely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased collagen production and fibrosis can be seen in CREST syndrome, which may be associated with esophageal dysmotility and reflux esophagitis. However, CREST syndrome is an uncommon condition and unlikely to manifest solely with reflux esophagitis; other features of CREST syndrome, such as calcinosis cutis, Raynaud phenomenon, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia, are not seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's history of intermittent retrosternal chest pain that worsens at night, in conjunction with the hyperemia of the distal third of the esophagus and the biopsy showing nonkeratinized stratified squamous epithelium with hyperplasia of the basal cell layer and neutrophilic inflammatory infiltrates, is consistent with GERD. Dysfunction of the gastroesophageal junction allows stomach contents to flow back into the esophagus, causing inflammation of the esophageal epithelium. Risk factors for GERD include dysfunction of the lower esophageal sphincter due to anatomical disruption (e.g., due to hiatal hernia), decreased tension (e.g., due to smoking), and transient relaxation (e.g., due to obesity).
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the esophagogastric junction

The Z-line (green line) marks the transition from the squamous epithelium of the esophagus (E) to the columnar epithelium of the stomach (S). The Z-line's physiological position (dotted line) is at the same level as the esophageal hiatus, recognizable by a slight narrowing of the lumen (N).

A Z-line located significantly proximal to this narrowing (as seen here) is diagnostic of a sliding hiatal hernia.

D) INCORRECT:

Spread of neoplastic cells, as seen in esophageal cancer, would be unlikely to cause this patient's findings. Nonkeratinizing squamous epithelium is a nonmalignant pathologic finding and does not occur as a result of the malignant spread of cells.

E) INCORRECT:

Metaplastic transformation of the esophageal epithelium is the hallmark of Barrett esophagus, in which normal squamous epithelium is replaced by metaplastic columnar epithelium. Long-standing reflux esophagitis can lead to Barrett esophagus, which is a precursor lesion for esophageal cancer. This patient's biopsy findings show nonkeratinized stratified squamous epithelium with hyperplasia of the basal cell layer rather than metaplasia, making Barrett esophagus an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Comparison of the mucous membrane of a normal distal esophagus to one affected by Barrett metaplasia: In reflux esophagitis, stomach acid damages the stratified squamous epithelium of the distal esophagus, which then becomes replaced by columnar epithelium and goblet cells.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical features and endoscopy and biopsy findings suggest gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman who was previously found to have a 3-cm area of Barrett esophagus is reevaluated with surveillance endoscopy. She has gastroesophageal reflux disease that has been well controlled on omeprazole 40 mg twice daily for the past 3 years. She has not experienced any heartburn, dysphagia, or unintentional weight loss. She denies use of alcohol or tobacco. Chest and abdominal examinations are unremarkable and show no signs of lymphadenopathy.
New biopsies from the affected area demonstrate low-grade dysplasia but no signs of esophagitis or hiatal hernia.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transesophageal endoscopic ultrasonography is not indicated in managing low-grade dysplasia in patients with Barrett esophagus. However, it can be used to evaluate tumor depth, local lymph-node status, and metastatic spread in patients with Barrett esophagus who are diagnosed with high-grade dysplasia or esophageal carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with Barrett esophagus who have newly diagnosed low-grade dysplasia should have the pathologic diagnosis confirmed by an expert gastrointestinal pathologist given considerable interobserver variability in the interpretation of esophageal biopsies. If the diagnosis is confirmed, the patient can either be monitored with surveillance upper endoscopy, initially every 6 months (but not every 3 months), or undergo endoscopic ablation of the abnormal area.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with Barrett esophagus who have newly diagnosed low-grade dysplasia should have the pathologic diagnosis confirmed by an expert gastrointestinal pathologist given considerable interobserver variability in the interpretation of esophageal biopsies. If the diagnosis is confirmed, the patient can either be monitored with surveillance upper endoscopy, initially every 6 months (but not every 3 months), or undergo endoscopic ablation of the abnormal area. Ablation is usually performed using radiofrequency energy, although photodynamic therapy and cryotherapy are also options.

Key learning point: The most appropriate strategy for managing Barrett esophagus with newly diagnosed low-grade dysplasia on surveillance endoscopy is either surveillance endoscopy (initially every 6 months) or endoscopic ablation.

D) INCORRECT:

A change in proton pump inhibitors is not warranted in a patient whose acid suppression is well controlled, as indicated by the lack of esophagitis on endoscopy.

E) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic mucosal resection is a management strategy for patients with nodular Barrett esophagus.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents with a long-standing history of poorly controlled acid reflux symptoms. He uses over-the-counter omeprazole, which partially relieves his symptoms. He reports consuming approximately 30 mL of whiskey per day.
His BMI is 35; otherwise, his physical examination is unremarkable.
He had an upper endoscopy 6 months ago, which showed evidence of a hiatal hernia and Barrett esophagus with high-grade dysplasia. A carbon-13 urea breath test is positive.
For which type of cancer is this patient most at risk?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alcohol use is associated with an increased risk for several types of cancer, including pancreatic cancer and squamous-cell carcinoma of the esophagus, but not esophageal adenocarcinoma. The annual incidence of pancreatic cancer is approximately 1 in 10,000 patients. Consuming 30 mL of whiskey daily does not substantially increase the risk for these cancers.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has several risk factors for esophageal adenocarcinoma, including Barrett esophagus, chronic reflux esophagitis, hiatal hernia, male sex, and obesity. In patients with Barrett esophagus, the annual risk of esophageal cancer is approximately 6% for those with high-grade dysplasia and 0.25% for those without dysplasia.

C) INCORRECT:

H. pylori infection also increases the risk for mucosal-associated lymphoid tumors, particularly when gastric atrophy is also present, but the incidence of this type of tumor is low (approximately 2 in 100,000 patients per year).

D) INCORRECT:

Alcohol use is associated with an increased risk for several types of cancer, including pancreatic cancer and squamous-cell carcinoma of the esophagus, but not esophageal adenocarcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Infection with Helicobacter pylori (which can be inferred from the positive carbon-13 urea breath test) increases the risk for gastric cancer, but this risk is small. The annual incidence of gastric cancer is approximately 1 in 10,000 patients.

A 50-year-old woman complains of heartburn that has recently begun to disrupt her sleep. Although she has had heartburn occasionally for several years, it did not prompt her to seek treatment until now.
Esophagogastroduodenoscopy reveals distal esophageal erosions and ulcerations, as well as 5-cm proximal displacement of the squamocolumnar junction in the distal esophagus, consistent with Barrett esophagus. Mucosal biopsy specimens obtained from the columnar segment confirm the presence of metaplastic intestinal epithelium without dysplasia — also consistent with Barrett esophagus.
Which one of the following options is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Proton-pump-inhibitor therapy for 12 weeks, then histamine-2-receptor antagonist therapy

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman reports intermittent dysphagia to solid foods — in particular, bread and meat. She notes occasional symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease but no weight loss, hematemesis, or melena.
An upper gastrointestinal series with a barium tablet is performed (figures 1 and 2). The patient is referred for an upper endoscopy, which reveals narrowing at the gastroesophageal junction (figure 3).
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Esophageal stenting is used to treat malignant obstructions and refractory peptic strictures, which usually cause progressive solid-food dysphagia.

B) INCORRECT:

An upper esophageal sphincter myotomy is the treatment for Zenker diverticulum, which typically occurs in older patients and causes regurgitation and aspiration.

C) INCORRECT:

Botulinum toxin injection into the lower esophageal sphincter can be used to treat achalasia, particularly in patients who are not candidates for surgery. Achalasia typically causes dysphagia to both solid foods and liquids, as well as regurgitation of undigested food. A barium esophagram classically demonstrates a dilated esophagus with a narrowed esophagogastric junction; this results in a bird-beak appearance caused by the loss of peristalsis in the distal esophagus and a persistently contracted lower esophageal sphincter.

D) INCORRECT:

Swallowed budesonide is used to treat eosinophilic esophagitis, which tends to occur in younger patients and causes dysphagia (predominantly to solids) and food impaction.

A Schatzki ring can be difficult to see on upper endoscopy but appears as a thin, smooth, circumferential membrane when the esophagus is widely distended, most often with an associated hiatal hernia.

questions.text:

He has been taking omeprazole 20 mg by mouth daily for the past 8 years, which has generally controlled his reflux symptoms, but he is now having heartburn after meals 2 to 3 nights weekly. He reports no nausea, vomiting, or weight loss. He recently underwent cardiac stress testing in the emergency department, which was negative. He has no family history of cancer and had a normal colonoscopy 2 years ago.
On physical examination, he has normal vital signs and is in no acute distress. His oropharyngeal examination is normal, and he has no cervical lymphadenopathy. Heart and lung sounds are normal. His abdomen is soft and nontender, and he has central adiposity.
In addition to increasing the patient’s proton-pump-inhibitor dose, which one of the following tests should be ordered?

choices.text: CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow study may be useful for evaluating dysphagia and swallowing disorders. It can indicate the presence of an esophageal tumor, diverticulum, or stricture, or suggest certain motility disorders, but it is not useful in evaluating for Barrett esophagus.

B) INCORRECT:

If esophagogastroduodenoscopy does not identify reflux esophagitis, Barrett esophagus, or esophageal adenocarcinoma, and the patient’s symptoms do not improve with increased acid suppression, then esophageal pH testing might be useful, to determine whether ongoing acid reflux is contributing to the symptoms.

Current guidelines recommend considering such evaluation for men who have chronic (>5 years) and/or frequent (at least weekly) symptoms of GERD (heartburn or acid regurgitation) plus two or more of the following risk factors for esophageal adenocarcinoma:

• Age >50 years
• White race
• Central adiposity (waist circumference >102 cm or waist-to-hip ratio >0.9)
• Current or past history of smoking
• Confirmed family history of BE or esophageal adenocarcinoma in a first-degree relative

Key learning point: Older male smokers who have frequent or chronic heartburn despite proton-pump-inhibitor therapy should undergo evaluation for Barrett esophagus and esophageal adenocarcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis may be useful in determining acute causes of chest and abdominal pain and are often ordered together for staging of malignancy. This patient does not have any clear indication for CT at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Abdominal radiography may be considered in the evaluation of acute abdominal pain when a bowel perforation or obstruction is likely. Such imaging would be of limited value in a patient without reported abdominal tenderness.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man with a history of hypertension and anxiety has had one year of heartburn that he describes as intermittent chest burning. His symptoms have increased in frequency during the past few weeks and now occur almost daily, typically after he eats but occasionally at other times of day (although rarely at night). He has had no abdominal pain, nausea, dysphagia, odynophagia, throat pain, hoarse voice, weight loss, shortness of breath, cough, or diaphoresis. Hydrochlorothiazide is his only medication. He does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol.
He is afebrile, his heart rate is 90 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg, his respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 100% while he is breathing ambient air. His BMI is 24. His physical examination is unremarkable.
He is started on famotidine but continues to have heartburn, even at a dose of 20 mg twice daily with breakfast and dinner. The famotidine is switched to omeprazole 20 mg twice daily, which he reports taking diligently 30 minutes before meals, but no improvement is seen over 8 weeks.
Esophagogastroduodenoscopy, performed after the omeprazole is held for 2 weeks, shows a small hiatal hernia, but no esophagitis or strictures, and a normal stomach and duodenum. An electrocardiogram and exercise stress test are both normal.
What is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Laryngoscopy can be used to evaluate for reflux-induced laryngitis; however, the findings are not specific to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and should therefore not be used alone to diagnosis reflux-induced laryngitis. This patient does not have throat symptoms to suggest laryngitis or other extraesophageal manifestations of GERD.

B) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow study is even less sensitive than esophagogastroduodenoscopy for the esophageal findings associated with gastroesophageal reflux disease and is therefore not an appropriate next step in this patient’s evaluation. A barium swallow study may be useful in the evaluation of dysphagia and swallowing disorders, but that is not the primary clinical issue for this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Screening for Helicobacter pylori is recommended in patients with dyspepsia but not in those being evaluated for gastroesophageal reflux disease.

D) CORRECT:

A patient with typical symptoms of heartburn can be presumptively diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and started on empiric acid-suppression therapy. Patients who are unresponsive to an adequate trial of proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy or who have alarm symptoms should undergo esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD). EGD allows for evaluation of the mucosa and can identify findings associated with GERD, such as erosive esophagitis, strictures, and Barrett esophagus (which would require diagnosis by histology). Upper endoscopy has high specificity for the diagnosis of GERD, especially in cases of erosive esophagitis, but it has low sensitivity because many patients with GERD have a normal esophagus on EGD. The most appropriate next step in the evaluation of a patient with typical GERD symptoms and a normal EGD is reflux testing to assess esophageal acid exposure, the frequency of reflux episodes, and the association of symptoms with these episodes. Such testing is performed either with a wireless pH capsule that is placed endoscopically and attached to the esophagus — or with a transnasal multichannel catheter that measures both pH and impedance in the esophagus for 24 hours.

Key learning point: When a patient has heartburn that does not improve after an adequate trial of acid-suppression therapy, and both esophagogastroduodenoscopy and cardiac evaluation are normal, the most appropriate next step is esophageal impedance-pH testing.

E) INCORRECT:

Esophageal manometry is not useful for diagnosing gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) because low esophageal sphincter pressure and motility abnormalities are not specific enough for this diagnosis. It is typically performed before a Nissen fundoplication for GERD, to rule out motility disorders, such as achalasia or scleroderma esophagus, that are contraindications to surgery. It is also used to evaluate for esophageal spasm as a cause of noncardiac chest pain.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman who has been taking omeprazole 20 mg twice daily for the past 8 weeks for heartburn reports that she continues to have a substernal burning sensation that occurs mostly after she eats but also when she lies flat and often when she wakes up in the morning. She has been taking the omeprazole after meals and reports missing very few doses. She has also initiated recommended lifestyle changes to avoid consuming trigger foods, drinking alcohol, or eating late at night. She has had no nausea, vomiting, regurgitation, early satiety, shortness of breath, diaphoresis, or weight loss.
On physical examination, she is afebrile, her heart rate is 75 beats per minute, her blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg, her respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 100% while she breathes ambient air. Her BMI is 30. Her heart, lung, and abdominal examinations are normal.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Recommend taking the omeprazole 30 minutes before meals
Stop the omeprazole and start pantoprazole
Perform a cardiac workup, including electrocardiography and exercise stress testing

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A substernal burning sensation that occurs mostly after eating and worsens when a person is lying flat is typical for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Obesity, as seen in this case, is a known risk factor for GERD. Patients who have typical symptoms of heartburn and no alarm symptoms can be presumptively diagnosed with GERD and started on empiric therapy with a proton pump inhibitor (PPI).

When a patient continues to have typical GERD symptoms despite taking a PPI, the next steps are to (1) determine adherence to the medication, (2) maximize dosing, and (3) ensure that the PPI is taken before a meal. The efficacy of PPIs is maximized when the proton pumps of the parietal cells of the stomach are maximally activated, which occurs when the parietal cells are stimulated to secrete acid after a meal that follows a prolonged fast. Therefore, the typical recommendation is to take the PPI 30 minutes before breakfast for once-daily dosing — and 30 minutes before breakfast and 30 minutes before the evening meal for twice-daily dosing.

Key learning point: When a patient with classic gastroesophageal symptoms is not responding to lifestyle interventions and omeprazole twice daily, the most appropriate next step is to determine the timing of omeprazole use in relation to meals.

B) INCORRECT:

If an upper endoscopy is negative, the next step is to perform esophageal impedance-pH testing. This test would allow the clinician to quantify the amount of acid reflux and evaluate whether the patient’s symptoms are associated with acid reflux.

C) INCORRECT:

For patients who have typical gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) symptoms but are not responsive to a proton pump inhibitor, an esophagogastroduodenoscopy should be performed to evaluate for erosive esophagitis (which may indicate ongoing acid reflux) or eosinophilic esophagitis, an allergic inflammatory condition whose symptoms may mimic those of GERD.

D) INCORRECT:

If symptoms persist despite optimal proton pump inhibitor (PPI) adherence and dosing, a trial of a different PPI can be considered. If this is still not effective, or if the patient develops alarm symptoms, further workup is necessary.

E) INCORRECT:

If a patient has atypical gastroesophageal reflux disease symptoms that include chest pain, a cardiac workup (including an electrocardiogram and exercise stress testing) would be appropriate before starting proton pump inhibitor therapy.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man reports having an intermittent burning sensation in his chest 3 to 4 times per week for the past year. The sensation occurs only during the day and becomes worse after he drinks alcohol or eats a large meal. He has tried to lose weight and avoid late meals and spicy foods, without relief. He has no dysphagia, odynophagia, nausea, vomiting, exertional chest pain, epigastric pain, early satiety, belching, or bloating. He does not smoke and has no family history of early cardiac disease or upper gastrointestinal malignancy.
He is afebrile and has a heart rate of 65 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 120/50 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 100% while breathing ambient air. His BMI is 22.5. His physical examination is unremarkable.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Trial of a proton pump inhibitor

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ambulatory pH monitoring is used to determine the adequacy of treatment in patients whose gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) symptoms persist despite proton pump inhibitor therapy — and also to confirm the diagnosis in patients who have persistent typical or atypical GERD symptoms but no evidence of esophageal mucosal injury on upper endoscopy. Ambulatory pH monitoring can be performed using either a transnasal catheter that stays in place for 24 hours or an endoscopically placed wireless device that is affixed to the distal esophageal mucosa.

B) INCORRECT:

Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) should be performed at initial presentation in patients who have alarm features; an EGD is also appropriate in patients with typical gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or dyspeptic symptoms who do not respond to an 8-week trial of a twice-daily proton pump inhibitor. EGD may also be used to screen for Barrett esophagus in male patients with chronic GERD symptoms (> 5 years) who have two or more risk factors for esophageal adenocarcinoma. Such risk factors include age ≥ 50 years, white race, central obesity, current or previous smoking, and a confirmed family history of Barrett esophagus or esophageal adenocarcinoma in a first-degree relative.

C) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow study is useful in the evaluation for esophageal anatomic abnormalities, including rings, strictures, webs, or other subtle anatomic changes, especially in patients with symptoms of dysphagia. It is not helpful in the evaluation of uncomplicated heartburn.

D) CORRECT:

Patients who have classic symptoms of GERD (heartburn or regurgitation) with no alarm features (dysphagia, odynophagia, gastrointestinal bleeding, anemia, weight loss, and recurrent vomiting) can be diagnosed presumptively and started on empiric therapy with a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) to confirm the diagnosis. The PPI may be dosed once or twice daily and must be taken before meals to be effective in suppressing acid. If the drug successfully prevents symptoms, it can be tapered off after several weeks, in combination with dietary and lifestyle modification (losing weight, avoiding meals before bedtime, and elevating the head of the bed when lying down); if symptoms return after the taper, the patient may require maintenance therapy with a PPI or a histamine-2-receptor antagonist.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial step for a young patient with isolated heartburn symptoms is a trial of a proton pump inhibitor.

E) INCORRECT:

Esophageal manometry should be considered in patients with symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and associated dysphagia who have a normal esophagogastroduodenoscopy. Manometry is useful in identifying alternative diagnoses, such as achalasia, as the symptoms of achalasia may mimic those of GERD. Esophageal manometry is performed using a transiently placed transnasal catheter.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man with a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease and hypertension presents with dysphagia. He reports having difficulty swallowing solids for the past 6 months, with the sensation that they become stuck in his chest; they eventually pass into his stomach on their own. He has had no dysphagia with liquids, no difficulty initiating a swallow, and no weight loss or halitosis. He has no known food allergies or environmental allergies. He has not started any medications for his reflux.
He is referred for upper endoscopy, which identifies a smooth, thin mucosal narrowing in the esophagus immediately proximal to the gastroesophageal junction (figure). The rest of the esophagus appears normal.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s dysphagia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Barrett esophagus is defined by intestinal metaplasia and columnar epithelium in >1 cm of the distal esophagus. It is often caused by chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease and is a risk factor for esophageal adenocarcinoma. It is generally asymptomatic and would not cause dysphagia.

B) INCORRECT:

Adenocarcinoma of the esophagus can manifest with dysphagia to solids and/or liquids. Diagnosis requires an endoscopy showing an esophageal mass and biopsy findings consistent with adenocarcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic esophagitis is characterized by dysphagia to solids and/or liquids and is caused by an eosinophilic reaction to certain foods or environmental allergens. Although esophageal rings can be seen in patients with eosinophilic esophagitis, there are also usually other characteristic findings on upper endoscopy, such as linear furrowing and mucosal fragility, which were not present in this case. To make the diagnosis of eosinophilic esophagitis, a biopsy of the esophagus is needed and would reveal more than 15 eosinophils per high-power field.

D) CORRECT:

This patient presents with dysphagia to solids but not liquids, and his upper endoscopy shows an esophageal ring immediately proximal to the gastroesophageal junction (GEJ). These findings are diagnostic of a Schatzki ring, a benign ring of mucosa that is both smooth and thin. A Schatzki ring can also be diagnosed with a barium-swallow study showing a focal narrowing above the GEJ. A biopsy is generally performed to rule out associated disorders, primarily eosinophilic esophagitis. The pathophysiology of Schatzki rings is poorly understood, but chronic exposure of the lower esophagus to stomach acid is thought to be a contributor. Treatment generally involves balloon dilation if there is dysphagia and proton pump inhibitor therapy to prevent recurrence or progression.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of dysphagia to solids but not liquids, when upper endoscopy shows a benign-appearing ring proximal to the gastroesophageal junction, is a Schatzki ring.

E) INCORRECT:

Achalasia is a gastrointestinal motility disorder characterized by increased lower esophageal sphincter (LES) pressure and an absence of normal contractility in the esophageal body. Affected patients often present with dysphagia to both liquids and solids. The diagnosis often requires esophageal motility testing to assess LES pressure and contractions of the esophageal body.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up appointment two months after she was diagnosed with asthma. Her symptoms have improved since starting inhaled albuterol and beclomethasone, but she still coughs most nights when she is lying in bed. Over the past 2 weeks, she has also had occasional substernal chest pain. BMI is 30 kg/m2. She has a hoarse voice and frequently clears her throat during the examination. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) may be considered to evaluate underlying cardiac pathologies. This patient's recurring chest pain, exertional dyspnea, and cough exacerbation when lying supine are possible symptoms of heart failure and lung edema. In some cases, severe mitral valve stenosis may lead to hoarseness due to recurrent laryngeal nerve damage by an enlarged left atrium. However, further signs and symptoms of heart failure such as peripheral pitting edema, increased jugular venous distention, nocturia, and tachycardia would be expected at this point. Moreover, except for obesity, this patient has no risk factors for heart disease (e.g., history of smoking, rheumatic fever, or hypertension), making a different etiology of her symptoms more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Salmeterol is a long-acting beta agonist that is used in the management of moderate chronic asthma. Salmeterol would be a reasonable next step in the escalation of her asthma therapy because this patient currently uses a short-acting beta agonist and a corticosteroid inhaler. However, other comorbidities that potentially worsen asthma should be treated before escalating asthma therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral prednisone is used to treat acute asthma exacerbations or severe, therapy-refractory chronic asthma. This patient does not present with acute dyspnea and wheezing, which makes an acute asthma exacerbation unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's persistent cough and substernal chest pain are consistent with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), for which obesity is a risk factor. GERD is a known trigger of asthma and is associated with difficult-to-treat disease. It is thought to worsen asthma as a result of chronic microaspiration of stomach contents into the upper airways as well as an increase in vagal tone. Asthma that worsens when lying down or after meals should raise concern for GERD-induced disease. Since this patient has only had a partial response to her recently initiated asthma medication, a trial of empiric therapy with a proton pump inhibitor is the most appropriate next step in management.
