However, this patient shows no signs or symptoms of allergic asthma (e.g., asthma triggered by allergens, such as dust or pollen; a history of atopy) and, therefore, measurement of serum IgE levels is not indicated at this time.
questions.hint: This woman should be evaluated for other conditions that could be worsening her symptoms. Obesity is a risk factor for another common comorbidity associated with asthma.

questions.text: A healthy 55-year-old man comes to the office because of a 5-month history of progressively worsening substernal chest pain after meals. The pain occurs almost daily, becomes severe after he eats spicy foods or drinks coffee, and often wakes him up at night. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years and he drinks one to two glasses of wine nightly with dinner. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows erythema of the distal esophagus with two small mucosal erosions. Biopsy specimens obtained from the esophagus show no evidence of metaplasia. Without treatment of his current esophageal condition, this patient is most likely to develop which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The most important risk factors for esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) are cigarette smoking and chronic alcohol use. However, GERD with reflux esophagitis does not increase the risk of developing esophageal SCC. Moreover, esophageal SCC typically occurs in the upper two-thirds of the esophagus, whereas this patient has endoscopic evidence of distal esophageal disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for laryngeal carcinoma include cigarette smoking and alcohol consumption, both of which are present in this patient. Reflux of gastric acid into the larynx can cause chronic laryngitis and in severe cases, laryngeal and/or tracheal stenosis. However, laryngeal carcinoma is not a known complication of untreated GERD with esophagitis.

C) CORRECT:

Esophageal strictures are common sequelae of untreated GERD and/or esophagitis. Reflux esophagitis (erosive esophagitis), the most common complication of GERD, is characterized by inflammation of the esophageal mucosa. Esophageal strictures are formed via fibrosis as the inflamed esophageal mucosa heals. Treatment of both reflux esophagitis and GERD consists of lifestyle modifications (e.g., elevation of the head of the bed when sleeping, avoidance of dietary triggers such as spicy food) and acid suppression with proton pump inhibitors.

D) INCORRECT:

Sliding hiatal hernia predisposes to GERD as the laxity of the diaphragmatic esophageal hiatus impairs lower esophageal sphincter function and permits the reflux of gastric contents into the esophagus. GERD, however, does not increase the risk of a hiatal hernia.

E) INCORRECT:

Gastric outlet obstruction (GOO) most commonly occurs as a sequela of peptic ulcer disease (PUD) and develops as a result of inflammation and edema in acute PUD and scarring and fibrosis in chronic PUD. Gastric ulcers typically manifest with postprandial upper abdominal pain worsened by caffeine and spicy foods, whereas duodenal ulcers can cause nocturnal discomfort, similar to the symptoms this patient has. However, this patient's endoscopy findings are in keeping with esophagitis rather than PUD. GOO is not a complication of GERD or esophagitis.
questions.hint: This patient has characteristic symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and evidence of esophagitis on esophagogastroduodenoscopy (esophageal erythema and erosions).

questions.text: A 37-year-old man comes to the office because of a 1-month history of an intermittent burning sensation in his chest. The sensation becomes prominent when he is lying in bed and is also present after eating heavy meals. He also states that his breath has an unpleasant odor in the morning. He has not lost any weight during this period. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Results of a complete blood count are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic examination of the esophagus to screen for adenocarcinoma is reserved for patients with GERD and alarm symptoms (e.g., dysphagia, odynophagia, anemia, GI bleeding, unintentional weight loss). It is also indicated to screen for Barrett esophagus in patients with chronic GERD symptoms (weekly for ≥ 5 years) and three or more additional risk factors: male sex, age > 50 years, White ethnicity, obesity, smoking, family history of Barrett esophagus or esophageal adenocarcinoma in a first-degree relative. This patient does not meet the criteria for endoscopy at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

H. pylori testing via urea breath test is indicated in patients with dyspepsia (i.e., epigastric pain or burning that lasts for ≥ 1 month) if they are < 60 years of age and do not have red flags for dyspepsia. This patient, however, has typical heartburn (intermittent retrosternal pain exacerbated by eating and lying down), the classic symptom of GERD. H. pylori testing is not recommended in the workup of typical GERD (i.e., in patients without dyspepsia in whom neither PUD nor gastritis is suspected). The prevalence of H. pylori infection among patients with GERD is not greater than in the general population. Test results would not help in the decision for or against the treatment of H. pylori infection in this patient group. Other indications for H. pylori testing include active peptic ulcer disease (PUD), a past history of PUD, atrophic gastritis, and/or gastric MALT lymphomas.

C) CORRECT:

Empiric therapy with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) is the most appropriate initial step in the management of recent-onset GERD with no red flag symptoms of GERD (e.g., dysphagia, odynophagia, anemia, GI bleeding, unintentional weight loss, persistent vomiting, aspiration pneumonia) and little to no risk factors for Barrett esophagus. Of all medications that are used to treat GERD, PPIs are associated with the greatest reduction in symptoms and relapse rates. In addition to a trial of PPIs for 8 weeks, certain lifestyle modifications (e.g., smoking cessation, weight loss, elevating the head of the bed while sleeping, avoiding late-night meals) should be recommended.

Key learning point: Empiric proton pump inhibitor therapy is the first-line treatment for recent-onset, uncomplicated gastroesophageal reflux disease without alarm symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

H2 receptor antagonists (H2RAs) is the second-line treatment for patients with GERD because they are less effective than first-line drugs in providing symptomatic relief, reducing relapse rates, and promoting healing of erosive lesions of the esophagus. H2RAs also have a shorter duration of action (about 12 hours) than first-line drugs.

Bedtime administration of H2RAs may be considered as adjunctive therapy for patients with symptoms refractory to first-line therapy. However, this patient has not yet received the first-line therapy and should therefore not be given an H2RA.

E) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow is the confirmatory test for esophageal diverticula (e.g., Zenker diverticulum), which can manifest with halitosis and retrosternal discomfort, mimicking GERD. However, Zenker diverticulum is more common in men > 60 years of age; moreover, additional symptoms, such as dysphagia and regurgitation of undigested food, are also expected in patients with an esophageal diverticulum.

Studies have shown that barium swallows have a very low sensitivity (approx. 25%) for diagnosing gastroesophageal reflux, and therefore, should not be used for the diagnosis of GERD when a patient presents with typical symptoms of uncomplicated GERD in the absence of dysphagia.
Image Description:

The predominantely left-sided, dorsal contrast-filled structure in the upper esophagus most likely indicates Zenker diverticulum.
questions.hint: The burning sensation in this patient's chest, exacerbated by consuming heavy meals and lying down, is consistent with heartburn, which, along with halitosis, is suggestive of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease presents with dysphagia. He reports having difficulty swallowing solids for the past 6 months, with the sensation that they become stuck in his chest; they eventually pass into his stomach on their own. He has had no dysphagia with liquids, no difficulty initiating a swallow, and no weight loss or halitosis. He has no known food allergies or environmental allergies. He is referred for upper endoscopy, which identifies a smooth, thin mucosal narrowing in the esophagus immediately proximal to the gastroesophageal junction. A photograph of the endoscopic findings is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s dysphagia?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient presents with dysphagia to solids but not liquids, and his upper endoscopy shows an esophageal ring immediately proximal to the gastroesophageal junction (GEJ). These findings are diagnostic of a Schatzki ring, a benign ring of mucosa that is both smooth and thin. A Schatzki ring can also be diagnosed with a barium-swallow study showing a focal narrowing above the GEJ. A biopsy is generally performed to rule out associated disorders, primarily eosinophilic esophagitis. The pathophysiology of Schatzki rings is poorly understood, but chronic exposure of the lower esophagus to stomach acid is thought to be a contributor. Treatment generally involves balloon dilation if there is dysphagia and proton pump inhibitor therapy to prevent recurrence or progression.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of dysphagia to solids but not liquids, when upper endoscopy shows a benign-appearing ring proximal to the gastroesophageal junction, is a Schatzki ring.

B) INCORRECT:

Barrett esophagus is defined by intestinal metaplasia and columnar epithelium in > 1 cm of the distal esophagus. It is often caused by chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease and is a risk factor for esophageal adenocarcinoma. It is generally asymptomatic and would not cause dysphagia.

C) INCORRECT:

Adenocarcinoma of the esophagus can manifest with dysphagia to solids and/or liquids. Diagnosis requires an endoscopy showing an esophageal mass and biopsy findings consistent with adenocarcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic esophagitis is characterized by dysphagia to solids and/or liquids and is caused by an eosinophilic reaction to certain foods or environmental allergens. Although esophageal rings can be seen in patients with eosinophilic esophagitis, there are also usually other characteristic findings on upper endoscopy, such as linear furrowing and mucosal fragility, which were not present in this case. To make the diagnosis of eosinophilic esophagitis, a biopsy of the esophagus is needed and would reveal more than 15 eosinophils per high-power field.

E) INCORRECT:

Achalasia is a gastrointestinal motility disorder characterized by increased lower esophageal sphincter (LES) pressure and an absence of normal contractility in the esophageal body. Affected patients often present with dysphagia to both liquids and solids. The diagnosis often requires esophageal motility testing to assess LES pressure and contractions of the esophageal body.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man presents with six months of intermittent hoarseness, a persistent dry cough, and a recurring sour taste in the back of his throat. Episodes worsen at night and occasionally awaken him from sleep. He notes occasional heartburn after large meals. He denies smoking or recent respiratory infections. He has tried over-the-counter cough suppressants with no relief. Physical examination is normal.
Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vocal cord nodules are associated with prolonged vocal use and typically present with endoscopic findings. The absence of vocal strain history and the presence of reflux-related symptoms make vocal cord nodules an inconsistent diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic sinusitis might be considered due to persistent cough from post-nasal drip. However, the absence of nasal congestion, facial pressure, or purulent nasal discharge, along with reflux-related symptoms, makes chronic sinusitis unlikely.

C) CORRECT:

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) manifests when gastric acid refluxes into the esophagus, potentially reaching the laryngeal area. This can cause hoarseness, a persistent dry cough, and a sour taste. Nocturnal symptoms worsen due to the supine position, which reduces acid clearance and increases exposure of the upper aerodigestive tract to refluxed material. These extraesophageal manifestations can occur even with a normal physical examination and may be subtle, especially when heartburn is only episodic. The underlying mechanism involves transient lower esophageal sphincter relaxations, leading to irritation of the esophageal and laryngeal mucosa.

Key learning point: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) can present with typical symptoms like heartburn and regurgitation, as well as atypical symptoms such as hoarseness, cough, and an unpleasant taste in the mouth.

D) INCORRECT:

Asthma might be considered due to nocturnal cough, a common symptom in asthmatic patients. However, the absence of wheezing, episodic shortness of breath, or chest tightness, along with the presence of reflux-like symptoms, makes asthma an unlikely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents with a 7-year history of frequent heartburn and a sour taste in his mouth, partially alleviated by antacids. Recently, he has noticed mild difficulty swallowing. He is overweight and reports a diet high in fatty foods (see report).
Upper endoscopy: Segment of salmon-colored mucosa in the distal esophagus
Which diagnosis best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Barrett esophagus manifests with metaplastic transformation of the normal stratified squamous epithelium in the distal esophagus into an intestinal-type columnar epithelium due to chronic acid exposure from gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Patients with long-standing GERD symptoms, such as persistent heartburn and regurgitation, experience continuous acid insult that triggers adaptive changes in the mucosal lining. The endoscopic observation of a salmon-colored mucosa is a distinguishing feature of this metaplasia, indicating the presence of columnar epithelium, which is more resistant to acid injury compared to normal squamous cells. Recognizing these morphological changes is critical given the condition’s potential to progress to dysplasia and eventually esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Key learning point: Intestinal-type metaplasia at the distal esophagus is indicative of Barrett esophagus, a condition associated with chronic GERD and a risk factor for esophageal adenocarcinoma.
Image Description:

Comparison of the mucous membrane of a normal distal esophagus to one affected by Barrett metaplasia: In reflux esophagitis, stomach acid damages the stratified squamous epithelium of the distal esophagus, which then becomes replaced by columnar epithelium and goblet cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Adenocarcinoma of the esophagus may develop after long-standing gastroesophageal reflux, but the clinical and endoscopic details do not support an invasive malignant process. The endoscopic finding of a smooth segment of salmon-colored mucosa is characteristic of metaplasia rather than a mass lesion, ulceration, or nodularity associated with adenocarcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic esophagitis typically presents in younger individuals, often with a history of atopic conditions. Endoscopic findings include circumferential lesions and longitudinal furrows, not a segment of salmon-colored mucosa. The patient’s long-standing heartburn, along with the endoscopic depiction, are more indicative of acid reflux–induced mucosal changes rather than an eosinophil-mediated process.

D) INCORRECT:

Esophageal stricture, a complication of long-standing gastroesophageal reflux disease, results from repeated acid-induced injury leading to scarring and a narrowed lumen. It typically presents with more pronounced, progressive dysphagia, especially to solids. However, the endoscopic description of salmon-colored mucosa suggests a mucosal change inconsistent with a simple scarring process.

questions.text:
A 2-month-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to frequent regurgitation after every feeding over the past four weeks. He remains generally comfortable and is gaining weight appropriately. He feeds with good appetite and has normal stooling frequency. There is no bilious material in the vomitus. Physical examination is normal, and no palpable abdominal masses are noted.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Congenital lactase deficiency leads to osmotic diarrhea and malabsorption after lactose exposure. The infant's normal stooling pattern and appropriate weight gain are inconsistent with the profuse diarrhea and failure to thrive seen in lactase deficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

Malrotation with volvulus is associated with bilious vomiting and acute intestinal compromise. The infant's nonbilious vomiting, comfort, and appropriate weight gain do not align with the emergency presentation and rapid decline typical of volvulus.

C) CORRECT:

Gastroesophageal reflux in infants results from an immature lower esophageal sphincter, causing transient relaxations that allow gastric contents to reflux into the esophagus. This condition is common in infants and manifests as frequent regurgitation after feeds. The infant remains comfortable and gains weight appropriately, with normal feeding patterns and growth. The absence of alarming features such as bilious vomiting or distress supports a benign course. This understanding of the pathophysiology underpins the identification of physiologic gastroesophageal reflux in early infancy.

Key learning point: Frequent post-prandial regurgitation in infants is often due to decreased lower esophageal sphincter pressure, leading to gastroesophageal reflux.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis typically presents with projectile vomiting, dehydration, poor weight gain, and a palpable abdominal mass. The absence of projectile vomiting, dehydration, and a palpable mass, along with appropriate weight gain, makes this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents with progressive burning chest pain for five months. The pain intensifies at night or after large meals. He also experiences occasional sour-tasting fluid in his throat and mild discomfort swallowing. He is overweight with a BMI of 28. Physical examination is normal. He denies any significant weight loss or anemia. Complete blood count is within normal limits.
Which diagnosis is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Esophageal spasm causes intermittent chest pain and dysphagia due to abnormal esophageal contractions. However, the progressive, burning chest pain that worsens at night and after meals, along with sour-tasting reflux, aligns more with reflux than a motility disorder. Esophageal spasm typically causes abrupt, episodic pain.

B) INCORRECT:

Peptic ulcer disease typically presents with burning epigastric pain, not chest pain that worsens at night or after meals. The sour-tasting regurgitation and mild dysphagia suggest reflux, not ulceration. The absence of weight loss, anemia, or gastrointestinal bleeding further reduces the likelihood of peptic ulcer disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic esophagitis often presents in younger individuals with atopic conditions and causes intermittent solid food dysphagia. The predominant symptom of burning chest pain after meals or at night aligns more with reflux. The patient's middle age and overweight status further support a reflux etiology, and there is no history of food impaction or atopic features.

D) CORRECT:

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) manifests with burning chest pain that worsens at night or after large meals due to gastric acid reflux into the esophagus. This occurs because of lower esophageal sphincter dysfunction. The patient's symptoms of sour-tasting fluid and mild dysphagia indicate mucosal irritation from acid exposure. Overweight status, with a body mass index (BMI) of 28, increases intra-abdominal pressure, predisposing to reflux. The normal physical examination and absence of systemic findings like weight loss or anemia suggest an acid-mediated process rather than a more complex pathology.

Key learning point: Heartburn and regurgitation that worsen at night or with increased intra-abdominal pressure are indicative of GERD, which can lead to esophagitis.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man presents with a 4-month history of chronic heartburn and regurgitation that worsen at night. He has partial relief from over-the-counter antacids. He works late hours, routinely eats a large meal before bedtime, and drinks two cups of coffee daily. He has a normal weight. Examination is normal. An upper endoscopy shows mild erosive changes in the distal esophagus. He denies dysphagia or alarming features (see report).
Upper endoscopy: Mild erosive changes in the distal esophagus
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical fundoplication is reserved for refractory gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or complications like large hiatal hernias. The patient's mild erosive changes and partial symptom relief with antacids suggest an early, uncomplicated stage of GERD. Conservative management with lifestyle modifications and pharmacologic therapy is appropriate, avoiding the risks of surgery.

B) INCORRECT:

H2 receptor antagonists reduce gastric acid secretion and are useful for mild, intermittent reflux symptoms or non-erosive reflux disease. However, the patient's chronic symptoms and mild erosive esophagitis require more potent acid suppression than H2 receptor antagonists provide. Tachyphylaxis limits their long-term efficacy, especially for nocturnal acid secretion.

C) INCORRECT:

Lifestyle modifications, including avoiding late-night meals and reducing caffeine intake, are important in managing gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). However, the presence of mild erosive esophagitis on endoscopy indicates mucosal injury, necessitating pharmacological acid suppression for healing. Relying solely on lifestyle changes would not address the acid-mediated damage.

D) CORRECT:

The patient's chronic heartburn, nocturnal symptoms, regurgitation, and mild erosive esophagitis on endoscopy indicate gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) requiring acid suppression. A once-daily proton pump inhibitor (PPI) is the preferred treatment due to its potent and sustained inhibition of gastric acid secretion via the H+/K+ ATPase enzyme in parietal cells. This promotes mucosal healing and reduces the risk of complications. PPIs are particularly effective in patients with erosive esophagitis, providing superior acid control compared to less potent alternatives. Patient education on lifestyle modifications, such as meal timing and caffeine reduction, should complement pharmacologic therapy.

Key learning point: Proton pump inhibitors are the most effective treatment for GERD, and lifestyle modifications are recommended as adjunctive measures to manage symptoms.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman, G2P1, at 24 weeks’ gestation presents with a three-week history of burning epigastric pain that worsens when lying down. She experiences occasional relief with small meals. She denies weight loss, hematemesis, or dysphagia. Physical examination and vital signs are normal.
What is the most appropriate initial step in the management of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

H2-receptor antagonists reduce gastric acid secretion and are safe in pregnancy, especially in the second trimester. However, for recent-onset, uncomplicated reflux symptoms, nonpharmacologic interventions are preferred. Lifestyle modifications, such as adjusting meal size and timing, often effectively manage symptoms without introducing pharmacotherapy prematurely.

B) INCORRECT:

Upper endoscopy is indicated for alarm features like dysphagia or significant weight loss, or when symptoms are refractory to conservative management. This patient presents with typical acid-related symptoms in pregnancy, likely due to hormonal effects. The absence of alarm symptoms suggests initial noninvasive interventions rather than immediate endoscopic evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) effectively reduce gastric acid secretion and are generally safe during pregnancy. However, for pregnant patients with classic reflux symptoms and no alarm features, initial management emphasizes nonpharmacologic interventions. Lifestyle modifications, such as smaller meals and positional changes, are preferred to minimize drug exposure. PPIs are reserved for persistent symptoms despite conservative measures.

D) CORRECT:

During pregnancy, increased progesterone levels relax the lower esophageal sphincter, and the enlarging uterus raises intra-abdominal pressure, contributing to gastroesophageal reflux. Dietary modifications, such as smaller, frequent meals and avoiding trigger foods, reduce gastric distension and reflux events. Positional changes, like elevating the head of the bed and not lying down after meals, use gravity to minimize reflux. These nonpharmacologic strategies address the underlying pathophysiology with minimal fetal risk, making them the most appropriate initial management for heartburn in pregnancy.

Key learning point: In pregnant women with heartburn, lifestyle modifications are the first-line management strategy before considering pharmacological interventions.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents with chronic heartburn and regurgitation that worsens at night. She has been relying on over-the-counter antacids for weeks, with only partial relief. She denies dysphagia, odynophagia, or weight loss. Her BMI is 36. Review of her diet shows frequent late-night meals and high-fat snacks. Physical examination reveals mild epigastric tenderness. Laboratory studies, including complete blood count and metabolic panel, are within normal limits. She seeks improved long-term symptom control.
Which recommendation is most likely to help reduce her symptoms?

choices.text: Structured program aimed at gradual weight reduction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The patient's symptoms of chronic heartburn and nocturnal regurgitation suggest a reflux disorder, not an infection. While Helicobacter pylori-associated peptic ulcer disease may require antibiotics, this patient lacks infection indicators. Her obesity and dietary habits align with GERD pathophysiology, where lower esophageal sphincter dysfunction is key.

B) INCORRECT:

Immediate upper endoscopy is indicated for alarm features like dysphagia, odynophagia, or weight loss, which are absent here. The patient's symptoms suggest GERD related to lifestyle factors and obesity. Without red flag symptoms, endoscopy's yield for serious pathology is low, and noninvasive management is more appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Sucralfate forms a protective barrier on ulcerated mucosa, useful for duodenal ulcers, but not effective for GERD. The patient's symptoms are due to reflux from lifestyle factors and obesity, not mucosal injury. Sucralfate does not reduce acid secretion or prevent reflux, which are central to her symptoms.

D) CORRECT:

Obesity directly contributes to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) by increasing intra-abdominal pressure, which facilitates gastric content reflux into the esophagus. This pressure weakens the lower esophageal sphincter, increasing acid exposure. Additionally, high-fat, late-night meals delay gastric emptying, exacerbating reflux, especially when supine. A structured weight reduction program reduces intra-abdominal pressure and improves gastrointestinal function, decreasing reflux episodes and promoting long-term symptom control.

Key learning point: Obesity is a significant risk factor for GERD as it increases intra-abdominal pressure, leading to acid reflux; managing weight can help control GERD symptoms.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman presents with a five-month history of retrosternal burning and sour taste in her mouth. She has been taking a once-daily proton pump inhibitor for eight weeks without improvement. She denies odynophagia or dysphagia. Physical examination is normal. Laboratory studies, including complete blood count, are within normal limits. She continues to experience severe symptoms (see report).
Upper endoscopy: Normal mucosal findings throughout the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum
What is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-resolution esophageal manometry assesses esophageal motor function, indicated for suspected motility disorders like achalasia. The patient presents with reflux symptoms, not dysphagia, and normal endoscopy suggests no motility pathology. It is not the appropriate next step for evaluating reflux.

B) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow study detects anatomic abnormalities like strictures or diverticula. The patient's normal endoscopy and absence of dysphagia or odynophagia suggest no structural abnormalities. It lacks sensitivity for diagnosing reflux events and does not provide quantitative acid exposure data.

C) INCORRECT:

Increasing the proton pump inhibitor dosage presumes acid reflux as the symptom driver. The patient has not improved with once-daily therapy, and normal endoscopy suggests no acid-induced mucosal injury. Objective testing, like esophageal pH monitoring, is needed to correlate symptoms with reflux events before modifying therapy.

D) CORRECT:

Ambulatory esophageal pH-impedance monitoring is crucial for evaluating persistent reflux symptoms despite optimized proton pump inhibitor therapy. It quantifies both acid and nonacid reflux events, correlating reflux episodes with symptoms. This is particularly relevant in nonerosive reflux disease, confirmed by normal endoscopy. By recording esophageal pH and impedance changes, it provides a comprehensive assessment of esophageal exposure to refluxate, confirming gastroesophageal reflux disease and differentiating it from functional heartburn.

Key learning point: In patients with GERD symptoms unresponsive to PPI therapy and normal endoscopy, ambulatory pH impedance monitoring is the appropriate next step to evaluate acid and non-acid reflux.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of burning chest discomfort that starts about 30 minutes after meals, particularly after large or fatty meals. He occasionally experiences a sour taste in his mouth and reports an intermittent nighttime cough. He has a BMI of 29 kg/m2. Physical examination is normal, and vital signs are stable. He declines invasive testing (see report).
Electrocardiogram: Normal
Which of the following pathophysiological processes is most likely responsible for his symptoms?

choices.text: Defective mucosal healing due to persistent Helicobacter pylori infection
Intermittent relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter allowing reflux of acidic gastric contents
Excessive gastric acid output from a gastrin-secreting tumor
Intermittent esophageal spasm triggered by hot or cold liquids

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Helicobacter pylori infection is associated with chronic gastritis and peptic ulcer disease, not GERD. It typically causes epigastric pain, not the postprandial burning chest discomfort and sour taste seen here. The symptoms align more with reflux than with ulcer-related pain.

B) CORRECT:

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is primarily due to transient lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation, allowing acidic gastric contents to reflux into the esophagus. This patient experiences burning chest discomfort after meals, a sour taste, and a nighttime cough, which are typical GERD symptoms. Factors like fatty meals and increased intra-abdominal pressure, often seen in individuals with higher body mass index, can exacerbate LES relaxation. The reflux of acid irritates the esophageal mucosa, causing the burning sensation, while reflux reaching the laryngopharyngeal area can lead to cough.

Key learning point: Retrosternal burning pain that worsens after eating is characteristic of gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which is caused by the reflux of stomach acid into the esophagus.

C) INCORRECT:

Gastrin-secreting tumors, or gastrinomas, cause Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterized by refractory peptic ulcers and diarrhea. The patient's symptoms, such as postprandial burning discomfort and sour taste, suggest reflux rather than the severe acid hypersecretion of gastrinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Esophageal spasms cause episodic chest pain, often triggered by temperature changes, and are unrelated to meals. The patient's symptoms, linked to large or fatty meals and occurring 30 minutes postprandially, are more consistent with reflux than with esophageal spasm.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man undergoes upper endoscopy for persistent heartburn. He has a 9-year history of chronic reflux symptoms. He is not on medications. Vital signs are normal (see reports).

Upper endoscopy: Segment of salmon-colored mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction
Biopsy: Specialized columnar epithelium with atypical cells consistent with low-grade dysplasia

Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical esophagectomy is reserved for high-grade dysplasia or invasive esophageal adenocarcinoma due to its invasiveness and associated morbidity. The patient has low-grade dysplasia, which carries a lower immediate risk of progression to cancer. Initial management focuses on less aggressive approaches, such as endoscopic therapies or surveillance, rather than esophagectomy.

B) INCORRECT:

Surveillance endoscopy every 3–5 years is appropriate for non-dysplastic Barrett esophagus. However, low-grade dysplasia requires more frequent monitoring due to the increased risk of progression to high-grade dysplasia or adenocarcinoma. Guidelines recommend surveillance at 6 to 12 month intervals or consideration of endoscopic therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopic Nissen fundoplication is typically reserved for patients with refractory gastroesophageal reflux disease symptoms who have failed optimal medical management or wish to avoid long-term medication. It is not the initial management for Barrett esophagus with low-grade dysplasia, as the patient has not yet attempted medical acid suppression. Fundoplication does not directly address dysplastic changes and carries surgical risks.

D) CORRECT:

Barrett esophagus results from chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease, leading to metaplasia of the esophageal squamous epithelium into columnar epithelium with intestinal metaplasia. Low-grade dysplasia indicates evolving epithelial changes, necessitating intervention to limit further acid-induced injury. Proton pump inhibitors reduce gastric acid secretion, decreasing the inflammatory stimulus that promotes metaplasia and progression to higher-grade dysplasia. They also alleviate reflux symptoms and promote mucosal healing. Initiating proton pump inhibitor therapy is essential in managing Barrett esophagus with low-grade dysplasia, while further surveillance or intervention is planned.

Key learning point: In Barrett esophagus with low-grade dysplasia, proton pump inhibitors like pantoprazole are the preferred initial management to control acid reflux and prevent progression to high-grade dysplasia or adenocarcinoma.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man with a 2-year history of gastroesophageal reflux disease presents to the clinic with frequent nighttime heartburn and regurgitation that disrupt his sleep. He has been on once-daily proton pump inhibitor therapy for the past month, taking his medication before breakfast and avoiding late evening meals. Physical examination is normal. Vital signs are stable (see report).
Endoscopy: Mild esophagitis
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Increase proton pump inhibitor dose to twice daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Esophageal pH monitoring is used when GERD diagnosis is uncertain or for surgical evaluation in refractory cases. This patient has confirmed GERD with mild esophagitis on endoscopy, making further diagnostic evaluation unnecessary. Treatment modification is the focus, not additional testing.

B) INCORRECT:

Prokinetic agents enhance gastric emptying and increase lower esophageal sphincter tone, useful in gastric dysmotility or gastroparesis. This patient has typical reflux symptoms and mild esophagitis, indicating acid-mediated injury rather than motility disorder. Prokinetic agents are not indicated without evidence of dysmotility.

C) CORRECT:

In patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) experiencing nocturnal symptoms despite once-daily proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy, adding a bedtime H2 receptor antagonist can be beneficial. PPIs primarily inhibit meal-stimulated acid secretion, but may not adequately control nighttime acid production, which is often histamine-mediated. An H2 receptor antagonist targets this residual nocturnal acid secretion, improving symptom control and aiding esophageal healing in mild esophagitis. This combination leverages the distinct pharmacologic actions of both drug classes to address acid secretion throughout the day.

Key learning point: In patients with GERD who have nocturnal symptoms despite PPI therapy, adding an H2 receptor antagonist at bedtime can help manage nocturnal acid breakthrough.

D) INCORRECT:

Increasing the PPI dose to twice daily is typically reserved for severe or refractory GERD. This patient has mild esophagitis and experiences nocturnal symptoms, likely due to the timing of PPI administration rather than insufficient acid suppression. Doubling the dose may not address the circadian variation in acid production effectively.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents with a persistent, nonproductive cough for three months that worsens when he lies down. He reports frequent episodes of heartburn and occasional morning hoarseness, but denies smoking. Physical examination and chest radiograph are normal. Pulmonary function tests are normal. He has tried over-the-counter cough suppressants without improvement.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient's persistent cough, heartburn, and morning hoarseness suggest gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) with extra-esophageal manifestations. Lying down can exacerbate reflux by reducing lower esophageal sphincter tone, leading to laryngeal irritation and cough. Normal physical examination, chest radiograph, and pulmonary function tests exclude structural lung disease and asthma. A trial of a proton pump inhibitor, which reduces gastric acid production, is appropriate to address reflux-induced laryngeal irritation and cough.

Key learning point: In patients with chronic cough and symptoms suggestive of GERD, such as worsening cough when lying down and hoarseness, adding a proton pump inhibitor can help manage reflux and improve cough symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Fiberoptic bronchoscopy assesses intrinsic airway pathology, such as tumors or foreign bodies. The patient's symptoms, including heartburn and cough worsening when lying down, suggest reflux-associated cough. Normal examination, chest radiograph, and pulmonary function tests reduce suspicion of bronchial pathology, making bronchoscopy unnecessary.

C) INCORRECT:

Inhaled corticosteroids treat inflammatory airway disorders like cough variant asthma. However, the patient's symptoms, including heartburn and cough worsening when lying down, align more with reflux-induced cough. Normal pulmonary function tests further argue against asthma, making inhaled corticosteroids inappropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

High-resolution chest CT evaluates subtle parenchymal abnormalities, such as interstitial lung disease. The patient's normal chest radiograph and pulmonary function tests do not suggest diffuse lung disease. Symptoms like heartburn and cough worsening when lying down indicate reflux-related causes, not parenchymal lung disease.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents with progressive difficulty swallowing solids over the past two weeks. He has a two-year history of gastroesophageal reflux disease partially controlled on daily proton pump inhibitors and reports worsening heartburn over the last three months. He denies weight loss, hematemesis, or melena. Physical examination is normal, and vital signs are within normal limits.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to evaluate his new symptoms?

choices.text: Empiric twice-daily proton pump inhibitor therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow outlines the esophageal lumen and is useful for assessing structural or motility disorders. However, it does not allow direct visualization or tissue sampling, which are crucial for detecting mucosal changes and confirming diagnoses through biopsy, especially in patients with a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease and new-onset dysphagia.

B) INCORRECT:

Esophageal manometry assesses esophageal motor function and is useful for motility disorders like achalasia. However, it does not identify structural abnormalities. In this patient with progressive dysphagia and gastroesophageal reflux disease, a mechanical obstruction is more likely, necessitating direct visualization methods first.

C) CORRECT:

Chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease can lead to complications such as esophageal strictures, Barrett’s esophagus, and adenocarcinoma, especially when new symptoms like progressive dysphagia to solids arise. Upper endoscopy is the preferred diagnostic tool as it allows direct visualization of the esophageal mucosa, assessment for inflammation, neoplastic changes, and structural abnormalities, and enables tissue biopsy for histopathologic evaluation. This approach confirms mucosal injury and guides management of potential premalignant or malignant conditions.

Key learning point: In patients with GERD and new-onset dysphagia, endoscopy is the most appropriate next investigation to evaluate for complications such as strictures, Barrett's esophagus, or malignancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Increasing proton pump inhibitor dosage is common for reflux symptoms, but new progressive dysphagia suggests a structural complication like an esophageal stricture. Direct visualization and diagnostic evaluation via endoscopy are necessary, as empiric therapy could delay identifying underlying mechanical obstruction.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to your clinic with a long-standing history of poorly controlled acid reflux symptoms. He uses over-the-counter omeprazole, which provides partial relief. He consumes about 30 mL of whiskey daily. His BMI is 35. Six months ago, he underwent upper endoscopy, which showed a hiatal hernia and Barrett esophagus with high-grade dysplasia. A carbon-13 urea breath test is positive. Which one of the following conditions is this patient at greatest risk for?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alcohol use is associated with an increased risk for several types of cancer, including pancreatic cancer. The annual incidence of pancreatic cancer is approximately 1 in 10,000 patients. Consuming 30 mL of whiskey daily does not substantially increase the risk for this cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Infection with Helicobacter pylori (which can be inferred from the positive carbon-13 urea breath test) increases the risk of gastric cancer, but this risk is small. The annual incidence of gastric cancer is approximately 1 in 10,000 patients.

C) INCORRECT:

H. pylori infection also increases the risk for mucosal-associated lymphoid tumors, particularly when gastric atrophy is also present, but the incidence of this type of tumor is low (approximately 2 in 100,000 patients per year).

D) INCORRECT:

Alcohol use is associated with an increased risk for several types of cancer, including squamous-cell carcinoma of the esophagus. Consuming 30 mL of whiskey daily does not substantially increase the risk for this cancer.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has several risk factors for esophageal adenocarcinoma, including Barrett esophagus, chronic reflux esophagitis, hiatal hernia, male sex, and obesity. In patients with Barrett esophagus, the annual risk of esophageal cancer is approximately 6% for those with high-grade dysplasia and 0.25% for those without dysplasia.

Key learning point: The cancer most typically associated with Barrett esophagus and hiatal hernia is esophageal adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease and a 25-pack-year smoking history comes to your clinic for evaluation of heartburn. He has been taking omeprazole for the past 8 years, but now experiences heartburn after meals 2 to 3 nights per week. On examination, he has central adiposity. In addition to increasing his proton-pump inhibitor dose, which one of the following tests should you order?

choices.text: CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis may be useful in determining acute causes of chest and abdominal pain and are often ordered together for staging of malignancy. This patient does not have any clear indication for CT at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Abdominal radiography may be considered in the evaluation of acute abdominal pain when a bowel perforation or obstruction is likely. Such imaging would be of limited value in a patient without reported abdominal tenderness.

C) CORRECT:

This male patient, who is age 60 with long-term gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) symptoms and a history of smoking, should undergo esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) to evaluate for Barrett esophagus and esophageal adenocarcinoma. Current guidelines recommend considering such evaluation for men who have chronic (>5 years) and/or frequent (at least weekly) symptoms of GERD (heartburn or acid regurgitation) plus two or more of the following risk factors for esophageal adenocarcinoma:

• Age >50 years
• White race
• Central adiposity (waist circumference >102 cm or waist-to-hip ratio >0.9)
• Current or past history of smoking
• Confirmed family history of BE or esophageal adenocarcinoma in a first-degree relative

Key learning point: Older male smokers who have frequent or chronic heartburn despite proton-pump-inhibitor therapy should undergo evaluation for Barrett esophagus and esophageal adenocarcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow study may be useful for evaluating dysphagia and swallowing disorders. It can indicate the presence of an esophageal tumor, diverticulum, or stricture, or suggest certain motility disorders, but it is not useful in evaluating for Barrett esophagus.

E) INCORRECT:

If esophagogastroduodenoscopy does not identify reflux esophagitis, Barrett esophagus, or esophageal adenocarcinoma, and the patient’s symptoms do not improve with increased acid suppression, then esophageal pH testing might be useful, to determine whether ongoing acid reflux is contributing to the symptoms.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to your clinic for follow-up two months after being diagnosed with asthma. Since starting inhaled albuterol and beclomethasone, her symptoms have improved, but she continues to have a nightly cough when lying in bed. Over the past 2 weeks, she has also experienced occasional substernal chest pain. Her BMI is 30. She has a hoarse voice and frequently clears her throat during the examination. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's persistent cough and substernal chest pain are consistent with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), for which obesity is a risk factor. GERD is a known trigger of asthma and is associated with difficult-to-treat disease. It is thought to worsen asthma as a result of chronic microaspiration of stomach contents into the upper airways as well as an increase in vagal tone. Asthma that worsens when lying down or after meals should raise concern for GERD-induced disease. Since this patient has only had a partial response to her recently initiated asthma medication, a trial of empiric therapy with a proton pump inhibitor is the most appropriate next step in management.

Key learning point: Gastroesophageal reflux disease can worsen asthma symptoms, especially at night, and should be treated with a proton pump inhibitor before escalating asthma therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral prednisone is used to treat acute asthma exacerbations or severe, therapy-refractory chronic asthma. This patient does not present with acute dyspnea and wheezing, which makes an acute asthma exacerbation unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) may be considered to evaluate underlying cardiac pathologies. This patient's recurring chest pain, exertional dyspnea, and cough exacerbation when lying supine are possible symptoms of heart failure and lung edema. In some cases, severe mitral valve stenosis may lead to hoarseness due to recurrent laryngeal nerve damage by an enlarged left atrium. However, further signs and symptoms of heart failure such as peripheral pitting edema, increased jugular venous distention, nocturia, and tachycardia would be expected at this point. Moreover, except for obesity, this patient has no risk factors for heart disease (e.g., history of smoking, rheumatic fever, or hypertension), making a different etiology of her symptoms more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Salmeterol is a long-acting beta agonist that is used in the management of moderate chronic asthma. Salmeterol would be a reasonable next step in the escalation of her asthma therapy because this patient currently uses a short-acting beta agonist and a corticosteroid inhaler. However, other comorbidities that potentially worsen asthma should be treated before escalating asthma therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

IgE antibodies are involved in type I hypersensitivity reactions, such as allergic asthma, and they can be used as a diagnostic tool. However, this patient shows no signs or symptoms of allergic asthma (e.g., asthma triggered by allergens, such as dust or pollen; a history of atopy) and, therefore, measurement of serum IgE levels is not indicated at this time.
questions.hint: This woman should be evaluated for other conditions that could be worsening her symptoms. Obesity is a risk factor for another common comorbidity associated with asthma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 5-month history of progressively worsening substernal chest pain after meals. The pain occurs almost daily, becomes severe after eating spicy foods or drinking coffee, and often wakes him at night. He has a 35-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily and drinks one to two glasses of wine with dinner each night. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy reveals erythema of the distal esophagus with two small mucosal erosions. Biopsy specimens from the esophagus show no evidence of metaplasia. Without treatment of his current esophageal condition, which one of the following complications is he most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gastric outlet obstruction (GOO) most commonly occurs as a sequela of peptic ulcer disease (PUD) and develops as a result of inflammation and edema in acute PUD and scarring and fibrosis in chronic PUD. Gastric ulcers typically manifest with postprandial upper abdominal pain worsened by caffeine and spicy foods, whereas duodenal ulcers can cause nocturnal discomfort, similar to the symptoms this patient has. However, this patient's endoscopy findings are in keeping with esophagitis rather than PUD. GOO is not a complication of GERD or esophagitis.

B) CORRECT:

Esophageal strictures are common sequelae of untreated GERD and/or esophagitis. Reflux esophagitis (erosive esophagitis), the most common complication of GERD, is characterized by inflammation of the esophageal mucosa. Esophageal strictures are formed via fibrosis as the inflamed esophageal mucosa heals. Treatment of both reflux esophagitis and GERD consists of lifestyle modifications (e.g., elevation of the head of the bed when sleeping, avoidance of dietary triggers such as spicy food) and acid suppression with proton pump inhibitors.

Key learning point: Untreated gastroesophageal reflux disease can lead to esophageal strictures due to chronic inflammation and subsequent fibrosis during mucosal healing.

C) INCORRECT:

Sliding hiatal hernia predisposes to GERD as the laxity of the diaphragmatic esophageal hiatus impairs lower esophageal sphincter function and permits the reflux of gastric contents into the esophagus. GERD, however, does not increase the risk of a hiatal hernia.

D) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for laryngeal carcinoma include cigarette smoking and alcohol consumption, both of which are present in this patient. Reflux of gastric acid into the larynx can cause chronic laryngitis and in severe cases, laryngeal and/or tracheal stenosis. However, laryngeal carcinoma is not a known complication of untreated GERD with esophagitis.

E) INCORRECT:

The most important risk factors for esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) are cigarette smoking and chronic alcohol use. However, GERD with reflux esophagitis does not increase the risk of developing esophageal SCC. Moreover, esophageal SCC typically occurs in the upper two-thirds of the esophagus, whereas this patient has endoscopic evidence of distal esophageal disease.
questions.hint: This patient has characteristic symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and evidence of esophagitis on esophagogastroduodenoscopy (esophageal erythema and erosions).

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the ED for burning retrosternal chest pain that began after a large late dinner this evening. She reports similar episodes 2–3 times per week for months, worse when supine and improved by antacids. She denies dysphagia, odynophagia, weight loss, hematemesis, melena, or exertional symptoms. Vital signs are BP, 128/76 mm Hg; P, 78; R, 16; T, 36.9°C (98.4°F); oxygen saturation, 99% on room air. Examination shows mild epigastric tenderness without peritoneal signs. ECG is nonischemic; high-sensitivity troponin at 0 and 1 hour is below the assay limit with zero delta. HEART score is 2. Chest radiograph is unremarkable. What is the most appropriate ED management?

choices.text: Discharge with an empiric once-daily proton pump inhibitor trial
Discharge on an H2 receptor antagonist trial
Arrange urgent esophagogastroduodenoscopy from the ED
Admit for observation and serial cardiac biomarkers
Start intravenous proton pump inhibitor infusion and consult gastroenterology for inpatient evaluation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct — With typical reflux symptoms, no red flags, a low HEART score, a nonischemic ECG, and negative serial high-sensitivity troponins, outpatient management is appropriate. An empiric 8-week PPI trial plus counseling on lifestyle measures (avoid late meals, head-of-bed elevation, weight reduction) and clear return precautions (dysphagia, GI bleeding, weight loss, persistent pain) is the recommended ED disposition after ruling out emergent etiologies.

B) INCORRECT:

H2 blockers can help mild or nocturnal symptoms but provide less potent and less durable acid suppression.

C) INCORRECT:

Immediate endoscopy is reserved for alarm features (dysphagia, bleeding, anemia, weight loss) or complications. This patient has none of these and improved with conservative measures; urgent EGD is not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Low-risk clinical features, a nonischemic ECG, and negative serial high-sensitivity troponins with zero delta make acute coronary syndrome unlikely. Admission for continued cardiac workup is unnecessary.

E) INCORRECT:

IV PPI infusion is used for upper GI bleeding or severe erosive esophagitis, not uncomplicated reflux. Inpatient GI consultation is unnecessary without red flags or complications once emergent causes of chest pain are excluded.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a 15-year history of intermittent heartburn presents to the ED after developing sudden solid-food dysphagia with drooling and retrosternal pressure while eating steak. Symptoms partially improved en route; he can now manage secretions and sip liquids but remains unable to swallow solids. He reports that this wasn't the first time and he has had 6 weeks of progressively worsening solid-food dysphagia and early satiety. Vital signs are BP, 128/76 mm Hg; P, 82; R, 16; T, 36.8°C (98.2°F). Triage weight is 76 kg; a clinic visit 2 months ago documented 81 kg, consistent with a 5-kg unintentional weight loss. Examination is unremarkable. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Arrange urgent upper endoscopy with biopsy
Eight-week trial of proton pump inhibitor therapy

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct — Progressive solid-food dysphagia with weight loss is an alarm feature for structural esophageal disease (benign peptic stricture or malignancy). The appropriate next step from the ED is expedited gastroenterology evaluation for upper endoscopy, which provides direct visualization, tissue diagnosis, and potential therapeutic dilation if benign stricture is confirmed.

B) INCORRECT:

While contrast esophagram can delineate the level and length of a narrowing, it does not allow tissue diagnosis or immediate therapy. In the setting of alarm features, relying on contrast imaging first can delay definitive evaluation and management.

C) INCORRECT:

Empiric acid suppression is appropriate for typical reflux without alarm symptoms. Dysphagia with weight loss requires prompt structural evaluation rather than empiric therapy alone.

D) INCORRECT:

Manometry assesses motility disorders, which classically cause dysphagia to solids and liquids. It is not the initial study when a structural lesion is suspected based on progressive solid-food dysphagia and weight loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Cross-sectional imaging may assist with staging once a lesion is identified, but it cannot replace mucosal visualization and histology. Obtaining CT first can postpone the definitive diagnostic procedure and delay treatment planning.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents for follow-up due to persistent heartburn. For the past 8 weeks, he has been taking omeprazole 20 mg daily before breakfast and has implemented lifestyle modifications, including dietary changes and elevating the head of his bed. Despite these measures, he continues to experience postprandial burning chest pain and regurgitation three to four times per week. He denies dysphagia, odynophagia, unintentional weight loss, or melena. His BMI is 31 kg/m². The remainder of the physical examination discloses no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in this patient's management?

choices.text: Add an H2-receptor antagonist at bedtime

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In the absence of alarm features, the most appropriate next step is to optimize PPI therapy. This is best achieved by increasing the dose to twice daily, administered 30–60 minutes before breakfast and dinner. This strategy provides more consistent and profound acid suppression throughout a 24-hour period, addressing both meal-related and nocturnal acid production. If symptoms persist after 4–8 weeks of twice-daily PPI therapy, further investigation, such as an upper endoscopy, would then be warranted.

B) INCORRECT:

An upper endoscopy is indicated for patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease who have alarm features (e.g., dysphagia, weight loss, bleeding) or for those who do not respond to an optimized trial of twice-daily proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy. Because this patient has no alarm features, optimizing medical management by increasing the PPI dose should be attempted before proceeding with an invasive diagnostic procedure.

C) INCORRECT:

Metoclopramide is a prokinetic agent that can increase lower esophageal sphincter pressure and enhance gastric emptying. However, it is not recommended for the routine treatment of gastroesophageal reflux disease due to its limited efficacy and significant potential for adverse effects, including extrapyramidal symptoms such as tardive dyskinesia. Its use is reserved for select patients with a confirmed diagnosis of gastroparesis.

D) INCORRECT:

Adding an H2-receptor antagonist (H2RA) at bedtime can be considered for patients with persistent nocturnal symptoms despite optimized PPI therapy. However, it is not the initial step for managing daytime, postprandial symptoms that are refractory to once-daily PPIs. Furthermore, tachyphylaxis can develop with H2RAs, limiting their long-term effectiveness.
questions.hint: This patient has refractory gastroesophageal reflux disease symptoms despite an 8-week trial of standard, once-daily proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a 2-week history of worsening heartburn and a new sensation of food getting stuck in his chest when he swallows solid foods. He has had intermittent heartburn for over 10 years, which he has managed with over-the-counter antacids. He has a history of hypertension treated with lisinopril. He denies weight loss or vomiting. His vital signs are stable, and his physical examination is unremarkable except for mild epigastric tenderness. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate a high-dose proton pump inhibitor twice daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While a proton pump inhibitor is a mainstay of treatment for gastroesophageal reflux disease, initiating empiric therapy is inappropriate in the presence of alarm features like dysphagia. An underlying structural abnormality, such as a stricture or malignancy, must be ruled out first.

B) INCORRECT:

Esophageal manometry measures the pressures and coordination of esophageal muscle contractions and is the gold standard for diagnosing motility disorders like achalasia. While motility disorders can cause dysphagia, this patient's long history of heartburn makes a mechanical obstruction from a gastroesophageal reflux disease complication, such as a peptic stricture, more likely.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's new-onset dysphagia is an alarm feature that warrants prompt investigation. In the context of long-standing gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), dysphagia is concerning for complications such as a peptic stricture, Barrett esophagus, or esophageal adenocarcinoma. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) is the most appropriate next step because it allows for direct visualization of the esophageal mucosa to identify these pathologies. Furthermore, EGD enables the collection of tissue biopsies to confirm a diagnosis and guide further management. Other alarm features for GERD include odynophagia, weight loss, and iron deficiency anemia.

D) INCORRECT:

A barium esophagram can be useful for evaluating esophageal motility and identifying structural abnormalities like strictures or large masses. However, barium esophagram is less sensitive for detecting mucosal changes such as esophagitis, Barrett esophagus, or early-stage malignancy. A different management step is preferred for evaluating dysphagia in this setting.

E) INCORRECT:

Esophageal pH monitoring is used to quantify esophageal acid exposure and is indicated when the diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is uncertain, particularly in patients with atypical symptoms or those who do not respond to proton pump inhibitor therapy. This patient has a classic, long-standing history of heartburn, making the diagnosis of GERD highly likely. The primary clinical question is the cause of his new dysphagia, not confirming the presence of reflux.
questions.hint: The presence of new-onset dysphagia in a patient with a long history of heartburn is an alarm feature.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents with a 10-year history of gastroesophageal reflux symptoms, managed with daily proton pump inhibitors, and reports intermittent chest discomfort. He denies unintentional weight loss or difficulty swallowing. He has undergone endoscopic surveillance for persistent Barrett esophagus over the past five years without significant changes. Physical examination and routine laboratory values are normal. He has no significant comorbidities and a normal body mass index (see reports).

Upper endoscopy: 4 cm segment of salmon-colored mucosa in the distal esophagus
Biopsy: High-grade dysplasia


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Escalation of proton pump inhibitor therapy only

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surveillance intervals for Barrett esophagus depend on dysplasia severity. High-grade dysplasia requires prompt intervention due to its high risk of progression to adenocarcinoma. Delaying treatment with a 12-month surveillance interval is inadequate and increases cancer risk.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical resection, such as esophagectomy, is reserved for invasive adenocarcinoma or when endoscopic therapy is not feasible. In high-grade dysplasia without invasive cancer, endoscopic therapies are preferred due to their effectiveness and lower morbidity compared to surgery.

C) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors reduce gastric acid and alleviate reflux symptoms but do not reverse high-grade dysplasia. High-grade dysplasia requires interventions that remove dysplastic tissue, as acid suppression alone does not address the premalignant process.

D) CORRECT:

Barrett esophagus involves the metaplastic transformation of squamous epithelium to columnar epithelium due to chronic gastroesophageal reflux. High-grade dysplasia in Barrett esophagus significantly increases the risk of progression to adenocarcinoma. Endoscopic ablation therapy, such as radiofrequency ablation, eradicates dysplastic cells while preserving esophageal structure. This minimally invasive approach aligns with current guidelines and effectively reduces cancer risk in patients with high-grade dysplasia.

Key learning point: High-grade dysplasia in the esophagus is a precancerous condition that requires definitive treatment, such as esophageal resection or endoscopic therapy, to prevent progression to esophageal cancer.
Image Description:

Comparison of the mucous membrane of a normal distal esophagus to one affected by Barrett metaplasia: In reflux esophagitis, stomach acid damages the stratified squamous epithelium of the distal esophagus, which then becomes replaced by columnar epithelium and goblet cells.
